notes: Mid-range Buick series spanning 1940-1958 (production halted 1943-1945 for WWII). Buick inline-8 engines until 1953, V8 from 1954. Multiple body styles. RWD. Positioned between Special and Roadmaster. Difficulty modifier 1.15 reflects 1940s-1950s vintage complexity, WWII-era production variations, and obsolete mechanical systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Super article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Postwar flagship full-size luxury sedan (1946-1958). Buick straight-8 engine through entire run. Introduced Dynaflow automatic transmission 1948. Multiple upscale body styles including convertible. RWD body-on-frame. Difficulty modifier 1.15 reflects postwar 1940s-1950s vintage complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Roadmaster article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fastback body style variant (1941-1942, 1946-1949, no 1943-1945 production due to WWII). Buick inline-8 engine. Sleek fastback design popular in postwar era. RWD. Available in Super and Roadmaster series. Collectible for distinctive styling. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects 1940s vintage construction, WWII-era gaps in production, and specialized body restoration. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Sedanette article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Early wood-bodied estate wagons (1940-1953, wartime production gap). Buick inline-8 engines. Real wood construction through early 1950s. RWD body-on-frame. Available in Super and Roadmaster series. Difficulty modifier 1.15 reflects 1940s-1950s vintage complexity and wood body restoration requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Estate Wagon article, December 19, 2024 revision.
